summary_visit.AdmissionSummary: A 67-year-old male with a history of COPD was admitted on 09/15/2024 for a COPD exacerbation following a 3-day history of worsening shortness of breath, productive cough, and increased sputum production. He also has a history of GERD managed with pantoprazole. On admission, he was tachypneic, using accessory muscles for respiration, with bilateral rales and decreased breath sounds at lung bases. Initial management included supplemental oxygen therapy, bronchodilator therapy with nebulized albuterol and ipratropium, corticosteroid therapy, and continuation of pantoprazole. Diagnostics included a chest X-ray and blood gas analysis. Pulmonary medicine consultation was obtained. Over subsequent days, the patient showed significant improvement in respiratory symptoms and oxygenation.

medications.name: Acetaminophen
medications.reason: Pain relief, recommended to replace frequent ibuprofen use

notes.note_content:
Date: 09/15/2024

Author: Emily Chen, MD

Subjective:

  • CC: Shortness of breath, cough, and increased sputum production.
  • HPI: A 67-year-old male with a history of COPD presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of worsening shortness of breath, productive cough, and increased sputum production. He reports increased dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. He also reports a history of GERD and takes pantoprazole 40 mg daily.

Objective:

  • Vitals: T 98.6°F, HR 100 bpm, RR 24, BP 130/80 mmHg, O2 Sat 88% on RA
  • Physical Exam:
    • General: Appears ill, tachypneic, and using accessory muscles of respiration.
    • Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, regular rhythm.
    • Respiratory: Rales bilaterally, decreased breath sounds at lung bases.
    • Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.
    • Extremities: No edema.
  • Medication Reconciliation: Ibuprofen 400 mg TID PRN pain, albuterol inhaler PRN, ipratropium inhaler daily, pantoprazole 40 mg daily, flovent inhaler BID

Assessment:

  • COPD exacerbation
  • GERD

Plan:

  • Admit to the medical floor
  • Supplemental oxygen therapy
  • Bronchodilator therapy (albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers)
  • Corticosteroid therapy (prednisone)
  • Pantoprazole 40 mg daily PO
  • Chest X-ray
  • Blood gas analysis
  • Consult pulmonary medicine

Date: 09/16/2024

Author: Michael Davis, MD

Subjective: Patient reports improvement in shortness of breath and cough. Denies chest pain or fevers.

Objective:

  • Vitals: T 98.6°F, HR 90 bpm, RR 20, BP 120/80 mmHg, O2 Sat 92% on 2 L NC
  • Physical Exam:
    • General: Improved respiratory effort.
    • Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm, no murmurs.
    • Respiratory: Rhonchi persisting in bilateral lung bases.
    • Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.
    • Extremities: No edema.

Assessment: Improving COPD exacerbation

Plan:

  • Continue current medical management
  • Consider adding antibiotics if evidence of infection
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation consult

Date: 09/17/2024

Author: Emily Chen, MD

Subjective: Patient reports continued improvement in symptoms. Denies chest pain, fever, or worsening shortness of breath.

Objective:

  • Vitals: T 98.6°F, HR 85 bpm, RR 18, BP 125/80 mmHg, O2 Sat 94% on RA
  • Physical Exam:
    • General: Appears comfortable.
    • Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm, no murmurs.
    • Respiratory: Decreased rhonchi bilaterally.
    • Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.
    • Extremities: No edema.

Assessment: Significant improvement in COPD exacerbation

Plan:

  • Continue current medical management
  • Discuss discharge planning with patient

Date: 09/18/2024

Author: Sarah Lee, MD

Subjective: Patient reports feeling much better. Minimal cough and shortness of breath.

Objective:

  • Vitals: T 98.6°F, HR 80 bpm, RR 16, BP 120/80 mmHg, O2 Sat 96% on RA
  • Physical Exam:
    • General: Appears well.
    • Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm, no murmurs.
    • Respiratory: Clear lung fields.
    • Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.
    • Extremities: No edema.

Assessment: Resolved COPD exacerbation

Plan:

  • Discuss discharge planning with patient
  • Counsel patient on the risks of long-term ibuprofen use and recommend switching to acetaminophen for pain relief
  • Instruct patient to limit ibuprofen use to occasional use and to consult with their primary care physician before starting any new medications

Date: 09/20/2024

Author: Sarah Lee, MD

Subjective: Patient reports feeling well. No shortness of breath, cough, or chest pain.

Objective:

  • Vitals: T 98.6°F, HR 80 bpm, RR 16, BP 120/80 mmHg, O2 Sat 98% on RA
  • Physical Exam: Unremarkable physical exam

Assessment: Resolved COPD exacerbation

Plan:

  • Discharge home with outpatient follow-up with primary care physician and pulmonary specialist
  • Continue home medications as prescribed
  • Encourage smoking cessation and pulmonary rehabilitation

medication_orders.name: Pantoprazole
medication_orders.recommendation_reason: The recommendation is to continue the medication due to evidence of chronic NSAID use, specifically ibuprofen, which may require gastrointestinal protection, as noted in the patient's data.

medication_orders.name: Prednisone
medication_orders.dose: Taper as directed.  Take 2 tablets by mouth daily for 2d then 1 tablet by mouth daily for 3 days.
